Watch this. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb14', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb14', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Iran's leaders sow chaos, death, and destruction. They do not respect their neighbors or borders or the sovereign rights of nations. Instead Iran's leaders plundered the nation's resources to enrich themselves and to spread mayhem across the Middle East and far beyond. The United States has launched a campaign of economic pressure to deny the regime the funds it needs to advance its bloody agenda. We asked all nations to isolate Iran regime as long as its aggression continues and we asked all nations to support Iran's people as they struggle to reclaim their religious and righteous destiny.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So President Rouhani did not waste time responding to that. He accuses President Trump of a Nazi disposition. Watch this. HASSAN ROUHANI, PRESIDENT OF IRAN (through translator): It is unfortunate that we are witnessing rulers in the world who think they can secure their interests better or at least in the short term right public sentiment and gain popular support through the fomenting of extremist nationalism and racism and through xenophobic tendencies resembling a Nazi disposition. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb15', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb15', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Joining me now Nigel Farage former U.K. Independence Party leader and a Fox News Contributor. Nigel, good evening. Good to see you tonight.

utterances.speaker: NIGEL FARAGE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Good evening.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: What did you make of President Trump's remarks about Iran and Rouhani's response.

utterances.speaker: FARAGE
utterances.sentences: Well firstly, Rouhani's response. I mean it's a bit rich for the world's first Islamic extremist regime that's now been in place for 40 years to accuse others of racism, extremism, and Nazism which frankly in many ways is all that they've encompassed over these decades. I mean this is I think without doubt the most dangerous unpleasant regime in the world. And Trump -- and clearly John Bolton being there now is a very important influence but Trump is calling on Iran. He's saying, look you guys are sponsoring terrorism, you're spreading it you know, across your borders. The deal that Obama struck with you did not work far from taming you, it made you worse. And I have to say, it's very interesting but of all that was said today at the U.N. by Trump, Iran is the most interesting thing because today of all days the European Union's Foreign Minister Mrs Mogherini who by the way is unelected but never mind, and she said today the E.U. is facilitating easier trade with Iran. So you have Trump on collision course with the European Union over whether Iran are the good guys or the bad guys.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: And you know, clearly this is all over the Iran deal and Trump's decision to pull out of the Iran deal and the E.U.'s pushback to that. President Trump clearly called for the allies to rally together. Is there anything that will change that in terms of the perspective from the U.K. or the rest of Europe? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: FARAGE
utterances.sentences: Well, as far as the E.U. is concern, no, they are committed to the Obama idea that we should treat around as our friends and that we should embrace them economically. The Trump-Bolton idea is these guys were given a chance with the Iran Nuclear Deal, they abused it. They became even more terroristic. They spread their bad message all over that region. So no, those new positions are uncompromising. From a British point of view, it's very interesting. Brexit which will make us independent ultimately the U.K. would have to decide are we with America or with the E.U.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: That's going to be a big moment in our relationship for sure.

utterances.speaker: FARAGE
utterances.sentences: A big moment.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Bret Baier sat down earlier this evening at the U.N. with the president of South Korea President Moon and he said something very interesting about the future of the nuclear program in North Korea. Let's play that. MOON JAE-IN, PRESIDENT SOUTH KOREA (through translator): Chairman Kim actually wants within -- to achieve the complete denuclearization of North Korea with President Trump within his first term in office. So in order to make progress, he wants to have the second U.S. North Korea summit as soon as possible. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Very strong claim. He says that Kim wants to have a denuclearization of North Korea within the first term of President Trump. Do you believe that?

utterances.speaker: FARAGE
utterances.sentences: Whether I believe it or not, the most important thing is world leaders who are set enemies sitting down talking together is a good thing. Winston Churchill used to say draw-draw is better than World War and I would welcome a second meeting between Trump of the North Koreans. I tell you what, no bad can come of it.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: You know, obviously the world body, the U.N. is a controversial place. The President said something today that got a chuckle from the crowd. And I want to get your reaction to this. Let's play that moment.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: In less than two years, my administration has accomplished more than almost any administration in the history of our country, America's so true. I didn't expect that reaction but that's OK. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: What do you think of that moment, Nigel?

utterances.speaker: FARAGE
utterances.sentences: Well, look, that was Donald Trump being Donald Trump. You know, Donald Trump will never ever undersell his achievements.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: FARAGE
utterances.sentences: He did it -- he did it in front of a very, very skeptical U.N. audience. They laughed. Whether it was with him or against him, it doesn't matter and it was the lightest moment of that speech because he went on from there to attack much what the U.N. stands for. And for me, I've got to tell you, Martha. I mean, I've spent 25 years fighting for national sovereignty against global bureaucracy and to me that speech today was an absolute joy. And in decades to come when people ask what was Trump's philosophy, what did he stand for? Do you know what? All of it you heard today in that speech.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Fascinating. Nigel, thank you very much. Great to see you tonight.

utterances.speaker: FARAGE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So who can forget this moment when Senator Cory Booker said this. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: SEN. CORY BOOKER, D-N.J.
utterances.sentences: This is about the closest I'll probably ever have in my life to an I am Spartacus moment.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Now, the New Jersey senator says that that had nothing to do with any presidential ambitions that he might have. Really? Chris Stirewalt has his own theory on all this. Plus this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Visual proof. So take it from me, Bigfoot, Erik Paulsen really exists. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: BOOKER
utterances.sentences: This is about the closest I'll probably ever have in my life to an I am Spartacus moment.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: We played it twice because it's so much fun. Cory Booker's Spartacus moment on Capitol Hill earlier this month had a lot of people speculating that he is preparing a presidential bid but the New Jersey senator insists that he is not thinking about 2020. His sights are set on the midterm elections and that is exactly six weeks away but curtailing New York Times "my priority is flipping Congress seats at home so that we're spent that -- so we are spending a lot of time raising money for folks which is something that's really needed." Really? Joining me now Chris Stirewalt, Fox News Politics Editor and Author of the new book Every Man A King: A Short Colorful History of American Populace. I highly recommend it. It is a great book. Chris, good to have you here this evening.

utterances.speaker: CHRIS STIREWALT, FOX NEWS POLITICS EDITOR
utterances.sentences: So Cory Booker is not running for president apparently. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, if you want to get extra help from Cory Booker or Kamala Harris or Bernie Sanders or any of the Democrats who probably are going to run in 2020 maybe be from Iowa. Maybe that would be extra helpful. Maybe it would be from New Hampshire, maybe it would be from an electorally important state. This is a charade and both parties do it every four years.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Sure, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: This is this charade you go through. Because if you get caught with your hand in the cookie jar, if you get caught going for the presidential before the midterms are done, you look like a heel. You look like you're selfish. So you're like oh, I would never do anything like that. It's so farfetched.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: It's sort of an unwritten rule even in you know, the work that we do. People are allowed to say to you I am definitely not running, and then they're allowed to say six months later I have decided -- I've changed mind.

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: Does this dress make my butt look big?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: All right, moving right along. Let's take a look at Florida because there's a new Quinnipiac poll that you say is very interesting. Florida is a state that Donald Trump won by I believe one percent.

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: It was close, 116,000 votes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So what do you think of this?

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: This is a huge shift and it's a shift that we also saw reflected in an NBC News Marist Poll that was also out today. But the Quinnipiac poll is -- I prefer -- that's one of my faves.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Why do you like it?

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: They do -- they have good methodology and they also share their crosstab so we can see how did -- how many Republicans, how are the Republicans voting, what are the independents say, and how, when --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: The (INAUDIBLE) voters.

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: And it's -- and they weren't a likely voter poll. And this is -- this tells me -- and also it tells me about the persistent lead that the Democratic gubernatorial candidate has in Florida, Andrew Gillum. The Democrats in Florida -- that something switch down there. Some switch, flipped in Florida. I don't know whether it has to do with Kavanaugh, I don't know if it has to do with something else, whether it's state issues about -- they've had this red tide --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: The red tide.

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: -- and all these stuff.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Rick Scott got shouted out of a restaurant himself or some public place recently over that issue.

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: So something happened in Florida over the last couple few weeks that has changed the climate they're in a pretty dramatic way and it's reflected in several polls.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Very interesting. All right, Arizona is another one that is going to be very closely watched. Kyrsten Sinema and Martha McSalley, this one is it's pretty tight.

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: You know I love this race. This is like my theory. On election night, when you say we're going to talk about Arizona, you're going to say let's go to Chris because I will say, this has been my favorite all along. You have two moderate female members of Congress running against each other in a state that is politically changing in a very close race.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: For the seat of Jeff Flake.

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: Yes. For the seat of Jeff Flake in a very, very close race. This one is going to be contested brutally and intensely every step of the way. It's going to tell us a lot about the climate, it's going to tell us a lot about the electorate and they are two -- they are two good campaigners that are running to good campaigns. I love to see it.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So here is a very interesting ad. People get creative, right. This guy is creative with--

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: I love to say I'm with you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: And I know you really like this one so let's play it. We get at Chris's reaction.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I started to wonder, did Paulson really do it? I mean where is the proof, some blurry photo taken from an hours away?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I love that it's universally understood that if you walk that way--

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: -- everyone goes back to the big foot in the woods picture.

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: Which is, I get this taken from when I walk down over the train station.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: When you said as you do the briefcase thing.

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: So Erik Paulson has a reputation, they are trying to stick Erik Paulson, the Republican incumbent in Minnesota and the argument being, he's never in the district, he's always at home. But using humor is a good idea. There is a famous Mitch McConnell ad from long, long ago where they are leading a pack of bloodhounds through the woods to try to find the missing congressman. They are going to find the missing congressman. Using humor is a good idea, a connection with voters, and they are going to remember this in the district long after they have forgotten attack at 1,137.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: And people always think, ha-ha, funny, when they think Mitch McConnell.

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: Here is the turtle, here is the turtle, that's all I can tell you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Chris, thank you.

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: You bet.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Thanks for being up here tonight. Good to see you. So coming up, more than two dozen professors at one school canceled classes in order to let their students protest Brett Kavanaugh. So, what does this say about Brett Kavanaugh situation? About college campuses? When we come back.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So in a sign of the times on college campuses, more than 30 professors at Yale Law School today canceled their classes yesterday so that the students could protest Judge Brett Kavanaugh. The question is, would they do the same if his supporters wanted to protest en masse, would their classes have also been canceled? The debate comes as we see him how much the higher education can shape opinions. In a recent Fox News poll, those with a college degree lean towards believing the accuser Christine Ford, while a .14 percent margin while those without a college degree seem to side with Kavanaugh by a 17- point margin. My next guest understands all of this. He argues that a lack of intellectual diversity is leaving students unprepared for the real world. Here and now is Greg Lukianoff, a speech lawyer, co-author of a New York Times bestseller, "The Coddling of the American Minds: How Good Intentions and Bad Ideas are Setting up a Generation of Failures." And there it is. So my first question for you, is, you know, first of all, these are law students that are protesting. And they have not yet heard the hearing.

utterances.speaker: GREG LUKIANOFF, AUTHOR, THE CODDLING OF THE AMERICAN MINDS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So they haven't heard both sides yet, so I'm wondering if that and of itself is a little bit of a problem?

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: Well, it's one thing as we talk about the book. Polarization is one of the threads and everybody has got their war hats on and universities which could be kind of increasing understanding between the two different sides, seems to actually be making it more intense.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, are they -- I love this word, catastrophizing.

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Like everything is suddenly catastrophe.

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: That we need to protest, right?

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: Well, we've seen this real sharp rise in anxiety and depression on campus and our answer to it is saying, we are teaching the generation the habit to be anxious, depress and polarize people so we really shouldn't be that surprise if they are anxious, depressed, and polarized.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: You know, I mean, we live in a world in a country that has, you know, a very strong economy.

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So many advantages, probably the safest, one of the safest countries that you could live in the world.

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: And yet they are terrified, they're scared, they anxious, they're depressed. What explains that?

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: You know, a lot of it I got to say it's parenting. It's the people from my generation.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: It's my fault.

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: They were pretty (Inaudible). Yes. It's like, you know, we're raising our kids as if it's much more dangerous than it's ever been before, when in fact it's actually safer than it's ever been before. And part of our job, you know, with this book is try to tell people that you can calm down a little bit.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: How do you advise parents -- it's probably too late for my kids. But I mean, how do you get them to, you know, lower the anxiety level.

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: And to understand that, you know, a lot of bumps come along the road, and you have to kind of expect them and accept them as part of the process.

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: Well, helicopter parenting has to go for one thing. Free play, one of the most simple things in the world, letting your kids go run around and solve some problems by themselves without your -- without parents having to get involve. And we really take that play part really seriously. Because what we're afraid of is we have a generation that's always looking to authority and power to solve our (Inaudible) and that's not even good for democracy.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So in terms of, you know, how you -- you talk about coddling the American mind, so that coddling is sort of built in to the university system, isn't it?

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, one thing that all universities need to do, and people are lamenting, we have to give up on the university who don't believe in free speech anymore but how many universities even bother explaining freedom of speech or (Inaudible) freedom and orientation?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, I've always felt that you shouldn't be able to graduate from college unless you have a course that teaches you liberalism and conservatism and allows debate to happen between people who feels strongly on both sides. Because I think a lot of kids graduate from college and they don't even really understand the tenets of both -- of both sides.

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: Yes. I think that if I could wave a magic wand, and having people do political debates where they have to take the opposite side from what they actually believe would help a lot with the proper understanding--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: You are going to have to retrain parents, though, right?

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: Yes. That's right. We are trying.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I mean, retraining parents is a big -- is a big part of this.

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: We are trying. Lenore Skenazy we talk a lot to her and she is a friend, this free range mom who wants us to sort of ease up on her kids and retrain parents so they are not so paranoid and polarized.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: But they arrest free range moms now.

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: That's the scary stuff of all.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: We talk about this in the book.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: The kid walks to the school and the parents get called down to the police station.

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: Yes. We say this absolutely. Step one, stop arresting people for letting their kids walk to school.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: That's incredible.

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: That's ridiculous. Greg, thank you.

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: Thanks so much, Martha.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Thank you very much. Good to have you here tonight.

utterances.speaker: LUKIANOFF
utterances.sentences: Thanks.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So coming up next, from America's dad. This is an unreal story, right. Look at this, this is Bill Cosby in handcuffs being marched out of the courthouse. I never thought I would see that when I was watching the Cosby show as a kid, but that's what we saw today. So here's the question about whether or not he will, how long will he be there, three to 10 years is what we're hearing. That story is up next.

utterances.speaker: KEVIN STEELE, MONTGOMERY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: Finally, Bill Cosby has been unmasked and we have seen the real man as he is headed off to prison.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: What a story this is. America's dad as he was once known is spending his first night behind bars as a, quote, "sexually violent predator." Late this afternoon, a federal judge sentenced Bill Cosby up to 10 years in prison for drugging and assaulting a woman over a decade ago. Prosecutors say the 81-year-old has finally been unmasked as the criminal that he is. Trace Gallagher live in our west coast newsroom with the details.

utterances.speaker: TRACE GALLAGHER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Hi, Martha. The district attorney in this case said that Bill Cosby was hiding behind his TV character Cliff Huxtable. He went on to say that was a fictional character but now the true Cosby has been unmasked as a violent sexual predator who will spend at least the next three years behind bars. When Judge Steven O'Neill read the sentence, he said, quoting Mr. Cosby, this has all circled back to you. The day has come, the time has come." Our producer in the courtroom said both Cosby and his accuser showed little to no emotion. Watch.

utterances.speaker: LISSA KAPLAN, FOX NEWS PRODUCER
utterances.sentences: I could see his back, he didn't react, he kind of just sat there. Andrea same thing, didn't react. They both were very calm. Andrea, at one point though, after the sentence was read looked to be like hunched over and kind of just looking down contemplating what had happened.

utterances.speaker: GALLAGHER
utterances.sentences: Of course Andrea, being Andrea Constand, the woman who was drugged and sexually assaulted by Bill Cosby. She didn't speak after the hearing but her five-page victim impact statement submitted to the court was powerful reading in part, quoting, "Bill Cosby took my beautiful young healthy spirit and crushed it. He robbed me of my health and vitality, my open nature and my trust in myself and others." The D.A. Kevin Steele praised Constand as a woman of strength and determination. Watch.

utterances.speaker: STEELE
utterances.sentences: She has been solid and steadfast, put herself out like this for years in front of a worldwide. It's extremely difficult for anyone. She's been a rock.

utterances.speaker: GALLAGHER
utterances.sentences: Dozens of other women also came forward claiming Cosby had drugged and sexually assaulted them but the statute of limitations on those cases had expired. As Bill Cosby was led out of the courtroom in cuffs and placed in the back of an SUV, his spokesperson said Cosby had been persecuted. Listen.

utterances.speaker: ANDREW WYATT, BILL COSBY'S SPOKESPERSON
utterances.sentences: They prosecuted Jesus and look what happened. Not saying Mr. Cosby is Jesus but we know this country has done for black men for centuries. So Mr. Cosby is doing fine.

utterances.speaker: GALLAGHER
utterances.sentences: Yet, the 81-year-old Cosby who is legally blind has now been booked into the Montgomery County Jail where he will be processed and sent to state prison. It remains unclear if he'll be placed into the general population, his attorneys are appealing the conviction. Martha?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Trace, thank you very much. So, coming up here tonight, new details that have just come in. We've all been wondering what the format is going to be on Thursday morning, we now know. We will tell you that in a moment. Senator Lindsey Graham on the committee with the new information, next.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Do you believe there should be an FBI investigation into these allegations and that a pause should happen and, you know, sort it all out? If there is nothing to worry about and nothing to hide, why not have that process.

utterances.speaker: KAVANAUGH
utterances.sentences: I want an opportunity a fair process. America is about fairness and I want a fair process where I can defend my integrity and clear my name as quickly as I can in whatever form the Senate deems appropriate.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: That was in reaction to the question about whether or not they believe an FBI investigation should take place. And to this, Judge Brett Kavanaugh speaking out exclusively to THE STORY as he called for fairness ahead of Thursday's hearing. We are getting some details now for the very first time tonight about the format and what all of this is actually going to look like at the Senate judiciary committee. Chairman Grassley and Ranking Member Feinstein will deliver opening statement. Dr. Christine Ford will deliver her opening statement with no time limit, where she will tell her story. There will then be one round of questions, five minutes each for each senator and Judge Kavanaugh will then get the exact same opportunity. Here now, South Carolina Senator Lindsey Graham who sits on that committee. Senator Graham, good to have you here.

utterances.speaker: SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM, R-S.C.
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Do you believe that this is going to go forward? What are the indications from her attorneys is this going to happen?

utterances.speaker: GRAHAM
utterances.sentences: If it doesn't happen I would be surprised because they've been asking to be heard. They are going to be hurt if they want to. They are going to pick our lawyer and they're not going to decide who goes first. You know, Senator Grassley has spent over backwards to be fair. Not one once of fairness has come from our Democratic colleagues about an FBI investigation. If you really wanted one, why didn't you tell us in July when you first got this accusation? What's the FBI going to investigate? You can't tell -- you can't tell the FBI the month it happened, you can't tell the FBI where it happened. What are they supposed to do? Go talk to your buddy mayor (Ph) in 1982? I have never -- Judge Kavanaugh says he wants a fair process, you come to the wrong town at the wrong time.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: What do you say to those who criticize you for that attitude about it who say you know, you are not open to listening to what she has to say?

utterances.speaker: GRAHAM
utterances.sentences: I would say this. If you really believe this was a serious accusation, why didn't you bring it forward in July? Dr. Ford is being abused as much as anybody else. She said she didn't want to come forward, somebody on the other side leak her name, not us. She's been a victim of this as much as Kavanaugh has. And here's what I'm telling your audience. This is an accusation that's 35 years old. You can't tell me where it happened or when it happened and everybody named in terms of having been there say it didn't happen. So what am I supposed to do?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: One of the questions is about the burden. Who bears the burden is.

utterances.speaker: GRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: And Senator Chris Coons said something quite remarkable about this. Here he is.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CHRIS COONS, D-DEL.
utterances.sentences: It is Judge Kavanaugh who is seeking a lifetime appointment to the Supreme Court, and do I think now bears the burden of disproving these allegations, rather than Dr. Ford and Ms. Ramirez.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Is that how it works?

utterances.speaker: GRAHAM
utterances.sentences: They must have missed something in law school. So here's what Chris is saying. And I like Chris. Judge Kavanaugh you have to prove to me that you were not at a party 35 years ago and you didn't sexually assault somebody at that party, but I can't tell you where it was and when it was. And here's what Kavanaugh said. I've never sexually assaulted anybody anywhere at any time, but under this construct he will have to prove 35 years ago he wasn't at a party and they won't tell him when it was and where it was, and how are you supposed o do that?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Good question. It's interesting, Joe Biden in 1991 said this about the presumption of innocence. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, FORMER VICE PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: Judge, with me from the beginning, and at this moment until the end, the presumption is with you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: It's remarkable.

utterances.speaker: GRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Well, we miss Joe Biden. Here's the presumption. Anything Trump, fair game, no rules when it comes to Trump or his nominees. They knew about this in July, they sit on it. We have an allegation that's collapsing. I've never been more upset than I am now. I voted for Sotomayor and Kagan. I didn't do this to them. Judge Kavanaugh doesn't deserve this. Ms. Ford doesn't deserve what happened to her. We're going to play this out. And I can tell everybody who is listening. That everything about Judge Kavanaugh screams this is not true. He is not Bill Cosby. He's not Weinstein. He's lived a good life. This is an allegation 35 years old that's unverified and I'm not going to ruin his life based on that. Show me something credible that yet to do it.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: With regard to the FBI investigation, do we have time to play this one other sound bite here? All right. Let's play Joe Biden also in 1991 talking about the rule of an FBI investigation. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: FBI does not explicitly in this or any other case reach a conclusion. Period. So when people waive an FBI report before you, understand, they do not, they do not, they do not reach conclusions.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: That's incredible. Everyone -- everyone on one side of the aisle on the Hill is screaming for an FBI investigation and, Joe Biden who is pretty much the standard bearer of the Democratic Party says quite clearly there, that is simply not what they do.

utterances.speaker: GRAHAM
utterances.sentences: The other side had this in July, they went seven weeks without bringing it up and they drop it a week or three or four days before we vote. The FBI has told me, we don't know how to help you. We don't know where to go, we don't know what town to go, we don't know what month to look at, we're not even sure about the year. So this is just an excuse to destroy this man's life. This is not about fairness, this is about destroying Brett Kavanaugh to make sure Trump doesn't get a second pick. It's about no more, no less, and in the process they are destroying Ms. Ford, too in my view. Something may have happened to her. I don't know her. I'm respectful of people who've gone through bad experiences but I have to use some common sense here and I've been a lawyer all my life. And you could not get a warrant based on this allegation. You can't tell me when it happened or where it happened and everybody says it doesn't happen.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Now you have the format you each are going to get five minutes. How is this going to reach with this other attorney involved and why?

utterances.speaker: GRAHAM
utterances.sentences: We're going to basically give her our time. It's pretty hard to interview somebody effectively in five minutes and stop so we are going to have a professional litigator who is trained to do this.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Who is this person?

utterances.speaker: GRAHAM
utterances.sentences: I'll let the committee tell you about it. It will be a trained professional. We're not trying to make politics out of this, we are trying to make sure that 11 politicians are not in the limelight here.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So none of you will question at all?

utterances.speaker: GRAHAM
utterances.sentences: If I have a question I'm sure I will ask it. But I want to turn it over to the person who has more experience than I do. I'm trying to tell people that this bothers me. I voted for their nominees, I never would thought have to do this to Sotomayor and Kagan. These allegations are collapsing and the second allegation couldn't even make it in The New York Times. And only God knows what Avenatti is going to say. Everything in this man's life screams that he's been respectful to women. When he's been in charge of women in their careers, they have nothing but great things to say.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Let me ask you this. Do you think that we will see a repeat from Cory Booker and Kamala Harris, the senators who try to stop the proceedings. Are they going to say Thursday morning, no way. We want an FBI investigation. We are not going to let this move forward?

utterances.speaker: GRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Come Thursday morning, Ms. Ford, Dr. Ford, will have a chance to come and tell the committee in her own words what happened. Kavanaugh will have a chance to respond and we've been ask questions. We are not going to move it, we're not going to delay it, just like in arsonist complaining about a fire. These are the people who put in this box.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: And the vote will be on Friday.

utterances.speaker: GRAHAM
utterances.sentences: And this vote will be Friday, and unless something new comes out to give veracity to a 35-year-old claim that I don't have today, I'm moving forward to.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Al right. Thank you very much, Senator Lindsey Graham.

utterances.speaker: GRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Good to have you with us tonight. That is our story on this Tuesday evening. Live from the rooftop here on Washington, D.C., we will see you back in New York tomorrow night at 7 o'clock. Tucker Carlson is coming up next with his show straight ahead. Thanks for being here, everybody. Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2018 CQ-Roll Call, Inc.
